qas.question: Along with the Six Ages, what other scheme did writers in the Middle Ages use to divide history?
What writer referred to the Christian period as new?
Who wrote the History of the Florentine People?
When was the History of the Florentine People published?
Who first divided history into the ancient, medieval and modern periods?

context: Medieval writers divided history into periods such as the "Six Ages" or the "<a0_0>Four Empires<a0_0/>", and considered their time to be the last before the end of the world. When referring to their own times, they spoke of them as being "modern". In the 1330s, the humanist and poet <a1_0>Petrarch<a1_0/> referred to pre-Christian times as antiqua (or "ancient") and to the Christian period as nova (or "new"). <a2_0>Leonardo Bruni<a2_0/> was the first historian to use tripartite periodisation in his History of the Florentine People (<a3_0>1442<a3_0/>). Bruni and later historians argued that Italy had recovered since Petrarch's time, and therefore added a third period to Petrarch's two. The "Middle Ages" first appears in Latin in 1469 as media tempestas or "middle season". In early usage, there were many variants, including medium aevum, or "middle age", first recorded in 1604, and media saecula, or "middle ages", first recorded in 1625. The alternative term "medieval" (or occasionally "mediaeval") derives from medium aevum. Tripartite periodisation became standard after the German 17th century historian <a4_0>Christoph Cellarius<a4_0/> divided history into three periods: Ancient, Medieval, and Modern.
